prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Cloverleaf setup 1: H2O 202-111 + OH+ 11-01
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This setup combines for the Cloverleaf QSO (z=2.5579) two lines observed in ALMA band 7. The principal line is the low-excitation H2O line: H2O 202-111. In another freely available baseband we observe OH+ 11-01 which is the principal outflow tracer. As free bonuses we observe CO(9-8) and 13CO(9-8). So: baseband 0: H2O 202-111 1: 13CO(9-8) 2: OH+ 11-01 3: CO(9-8)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The linewidth is about 500 km/s and the velocity resolution for a 31.25 MHz channel is of the order of 30 km/s, which is easily sufficient.
At the chosen resolution we will get about 12 independent beams over the Cloverleaf, so that we will just begin to resolve the emission.

We have calculated the emission line fluxes by assuming the same line ratios as in Mrk231, scaling the fluxes from CO(7-6) which is observed in all objects. This results in a flux integral of 28 Jy km/s for the H2O line. The linewidth is 500 km/s and the emission will be resolved in about 12 independent beams. Aiming for 5 sigma at 31.25 MHz resolution (slightly more than 30 km/s), the target line rms is 1 mJy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Cloverleaf setup 2: H2O 321-312 + H2O+ 111-000 + H2O 111-000
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This setup combines for the Cloverleaf QSO (z=2.5579) three lines observed in ALMA band 7. The principal line is the high-excitation H2O line: H2O 321-312. In other freely available baseband we observe H2O+ 111-000 and the H2O ortho groundstate 111-000 which are the principal outflow tracers. As free bonus we observe CO(10-9). So: baseband 0: H2O 111-000 1: H2O+ 111-000 2: CO(10-9) 3: H2O 321-312

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The FWHM linewidth is about 500 km/s and the velocity resolution for a 31.25 MHz channel is of the order of 30 km/s which is easily sufficient.
At the chosen resolution we will have about 12 independent beams over the Cloverleaf, so that we are just beginning to resolve the emission.

We have calculated emission line fluxes by assuming the same line ratios as in Mrk231, scaling with CO(7-6), which is observed in all objects. This results in a flux integral of 23 Jy km/s for the H2O 321-312 line. The linewidth is 500 km/s and the emission will be resolved in about 12 independent beams. Aiming for 5 sigma at a resolution of 31.25 MHz (of the order of 30 km/s) the target line rms is 0.8 mJy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Cloverleaf setup 3: H2O 422-413
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This setup combines for the Cloverleaf QSO (z=2.5579) two lines observed in ALMA band 7. The principal line is the high-excitation H2O line: H2O 422-413. In other freely available baseband we get a second shot at H2O 321-312. As free bonus we observe 13CO(11-10). So: baseband 1: H2O 321-312 2: H2O 422-413 3: 13CO(11-10)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The FWHM linewidth is about 500 km/s so the velocity resolution of 60 km/s which is easily sufficient.
At the chosen angular resolution we will have about 12 independent beams over de Cloverleaf, so that we just begin to resolve the emission.

We have calculated expected line fluxes by assuming the same line ratios as in Mrk231, scaling with CO(7-6), which is detected in all objects. This gives a flux integral of 9 Jy km/s for the H2O line. The line width is about 500 km/s and the emission is resolved into about 12 independent beams. Aiming for 5sigma at a velodity resolution of 60 km/s the target line rms is 0.3 mJy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Eyelash setup 1: H2O 202-111 + OH+ 11-01
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This setup combines for the Cosmic Eyslash (z=2.327) two lines observed in ALMA band 7. The principal line is the low-excitation H2O line: H2O 202-111. In another freely available baseband we observe OH+ 11-01 which is the principal outflow tracer. As free bonus we observe 13CO(9-8). So: baseband 0: H2O 202-111 1: 13CO(9-8) 3: OH+ 11-01

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The FWHM linewidth is about 250 km/s and the velocity resolution for a 31.25 MHz channel is of the order of 30 km/s which is easily sufficient.
The resolution has been chosen such that we have about 20 independent beams over the Eyelash.

We have calculated expected line fluxes by assuming the same line ratios as in Mrk231, scaling with CO(7-6) which is detected in all targets. This predicts a flux integral of 8.6 Jy km/s for the H2O line 202-111. Our detection of the (fainter!) H2O 321-312 line in the only science goal carried out so far in this programme shows that this calculation is correct. At the chosen resolution we will resolve the Eyleash in about 20 independent beams. Aiming for 5 sigma at a velocity resolution of 50 km/s (the line has a 300 km/s velocity resolution) our target line rms is 0.3 mJy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SDP17b H2O 2_02-1_11 and OH+ 1_1-0_1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This observes the low-excitation H2O 2_02-1_11 line in SDP17b, and the excellent outflow tracer OH+ 1_1 - 0_1. We may get 13CO(9-8) as a bonus in another subband.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The measured total flux in the H2O line is 8 Jy km/s (Omont et al 2013, AA 551, A115 - PdB data). The source size is 1" diameter (Bussman et al - SMA data, arXiv/1309.0836). So 0.25" is sufficient and necessary to get spatial resolution. The line width is 300 km/s (Omont et al 2013). So at 50 km/s resolution we get about 6 resolution elements over the line, sufficient and necessary for simple kinematics. Per beam the line flux density will be about 2 mJy. We aim for a 5 sigma detection of this at 50 km/s resolution. The OH+ line is typically of similar strength to the H2O line, so this calculation is also vaid for OH+. Given that the largest angular structure will be 1" there is no need for the ACA, and we will recover all flux.
The FWHM line width is about 300 km/s so 50 km/s velocity resolution is easily sufficient.
The source size is 1" so 0.25" is sufficient and necessary for spatial resolution.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SDP17b H2O 3_21-3_12 and continuum
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This observes the high-excitation H2O 3_21-3_12 line in SDP17b. The 3 other subbands will provide a sensitive continuum measurement.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The H2O 3_21-3_12 line is about twice as luminous as 2_02-1_11 (Yang et al. 2013, ApJ 771, L24). Since the measured total flux in the H2O 2_02-1_11 line is 8 Jy km/s (Omont et al 2013, AA 551, A115 - PdB data), we expect a line flux in the 3_21-3_12 line of about 16 Jy km/s. The source size is 1" diameter (Bussman et al - SMA data, arXiv/1309.0836). So 0.25" is sufficient and necessary to get spatial resolution. The line width is 300 km/s (Omont et al 2013). So with at 50 km/s resolution we get about 6 resolution elements over the line, sufficient and necessary for simple kinematics. Per beam the line flux density will be about 3.3 mJy. We aim for a 5 sigma detection of this at 50 km/s resolution. Given that the largest structure will be about 1", there is no need for ACA, and we will recover all flux.
the FWHM linewidth is about 300 km/s so 50 km/s velocity resolution is easily sufficient.
The sources size is about 1" so 0.25" is necessary and sufficient for spatial resolution.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SDP17b H2O 2_11-2_02 and CO(7-6) /[CI]
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This observes H2O 211-202, and in the other sideband CO(7-6) and [CI] in SDP17b.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The H2O 2_11-2_02 line has typically 75% of the flux of the H2O 2_02-1_11 line (Yang et al 2013, ApJ 771, L24). The measured total flux in the H2O 2_02-1_11 line is 8 Jy km/s (Omont et al 2013, AA 551, A115 - PdB data), so we expect about 6 Jy km/s in the H2O 2_11-2_02 line. The source size is 1" diameter (Bussman et al - SMA data, arXiv/1309.0836). So 0.25" is sufficient and necessary to get spatial resolution. The line width is 300 km/s (Omont et al 2013). So at 50 km/s resolution we get about 6 resolution elements over the line, sufficient and necessary for simple kinematics. Per beam the line flux density will be about 1.25 mJy. We aim for a 5 sigma detection of this at 50 km/s resolution.
The FWHM linewidth is about 300 km/s so a 50 km/s velocity resolution is easily sufficient.
The source size is about 1" so 0.25" is sufficient and necessary for spatial resolution.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Water lines provide a unique probe of luminous IR galaxies, since (unlike e.g. CO) they measure the local IR radiation field. Herschel has shown that all local ULIRGs emit strong H2O lines, from highly obscured (FIR-opaque), IR-luminous regions with high local IR radiation pressures, which may play a role in driving the molecular outflows. We will take a major step forward with the first spatially resolved study of H2O emission (3 lines, providing the full diagnostic power), FIR continuum, OH+ emission/absorption (tracing the molecular outflow) and CO(7-6) and [CI] (tracing the high and low excitation molecular gas). We will observe these lines in 3 gravitationally lensed galaxies (Cloverleaf, Eyelash and SDP17b at z=2-2.5), at 0.2-0.25" resolution, obtaining the full position dependence of excitation conditions, importance of radiation pressure, occurence and velocity of outflow, and relation to the underlying gas disk. This is a resubmission of uncompleted observations from programs rated in the highest priority bin in Cycles 1 and 2.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00175 and 2013.1.00569. These were approved in the highest priority category but only 1 science goal was carried out (out of 8). This is a resubmission of the other 7. No duplication is requested: should more data come in under the old proposals, then the SBs will be deleted from the present program.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
